bioghist.p: Joseph Leidy (1823-1891) was one of the preeminent figures in the development of American science in the nineteenth century. He was a physician, naturalist, anatomist, and scientific illustrator. Following William Wagner's death in 1885, Leidy assumed the role of President of the Faculty of the Wagner Free Institute of Science, with special direction of the Biology Department. Leidy was Chairman of the Board of Curators at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia, and is a central figure in that institution's history. He also taught courses at the University of Pennsylvania and at Swarthmore College.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Joseph Leidy's original drawings created to illustrate his scientific writings. The originals are done in graphite pencil, ink, and watercolor on a variety of supports including small cards, onion skin, and the backs of social invitations and announcements. Most drawings are annotated and some carry a date. Included are many drawings from Leidy's Fresh-water rhizopods of North America (United States Geological Survey, v. 12, 1879). Also included in the collection is a brief personal note from Leidy to Joseph Willcox, dated 1890.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
